IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
TFC Wilson #6512
Maryland State Police
Golden Ring Barrack

 Assigned patrol vehicle, unmarked unit R-21, and I are equipped with an Axon camera. This incident was recorded.

APPLICABLE CERTIFICATIONS & TRAINING

*October 24-28, 2022: Certified EC/IR II Breath Test Operator
*May 7, 2020: Traffic Safety Specialist - Program Designation I
*September 23-27, 2019: Basic Criminal Investigation
*February 22, 2017: A.R.I.D.E. (16 hours)
*Certified Preliminary Breath Test Operator
*September 1-4, 2014: USDOT NHTSA DWI Detection and SFST Course
*June 23, 2014-December 12, 2014: Maryland State Police Academy, Class 142, Treasurer

 _____________________________________________________________________________

 
Defendant:

Ocampo Cardona, Hector Emilio

Address:
4022 Cedar Mills Rd
Randallstown, MD 21133

Vehicle:
PA 3982889
Blue Honda Civic

DUI# 23-004

Vehicle in Motion and Personal Contact:

            On 1/1/2023 at approximately 1502hrs I, TFC Wilson #6512, responded to the report of a single vehicle collision on the inner loop I-695 in the area of exit 35. I arrived in the area at approximately 1508hrs and located a blue Honda Civic later identified to be bearing expired Pennsylvania temporary registration 3982889 with extensive front end damage in lane 2. The vehicle appeared to be abandoned.

            Just ahead of the collision, I observed a male subject actively walking away from the scene and was currently on the right shoulder. As I was utilizing my unmarked patrol vehicle siren to assist with traffic control, I observed the male began running. I then directed my attention to that subject. As I maneuvered my patrol vehicle to the shoulder, he continued to run. I exited my patrol vehicle and order the subject to stop by giving loud verbal commands to do so. The subject failed to stop, scaled the concrete barrier wall, and ran into the wood line. I began to pursue the subject on foot. I continued to give loud verbal commands to stop. The subject ran through the wooded creek area which paralleled I-695.

            After a short foot pursuit, the subject lost his balance and fell into the creek. He was immediately detained without incident. A good Samaritan named, Kelvin Johnson, assisted with escorting the subject back to I-695.

            The subject detained was later identified as Hector Emilio Ocampo Cardona (H/M DOB 09/04/1993) by his Honduras passport which was on his person. Also, on Ocampo Cardona’s person was a North Carolina registration document for a 2010 Honda Civc with the VIN of 2HGFA1F56AH559129. The registration document was valid and advised the owner was Ocampo Cardona Construction in North Carolina. The VIN for the registration was later revealed to match the VIN of the Honda left abandoned in the roadway. Ocampo Cardona also had a key for a Honda on his person. This key was later found to be the key for the Honda that was left abandoned in the roadway.

            TFC Lora #7207 assisted with Spanish translation. I was advised Ocampo Cardona admitted to owning and driving the Honda and coming from Dundalk. I was advised Ocampo Cardona ran because he was scared.

            While interacting with Ocampo Cardona, I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person. TFC Lora advised me that Ocampo Cardona admitted to drinking alcohol. Ocampo Cardona was evaluated from medical personnel and refused transport on scene. It was discovered Ocampo Cardona had a seatbelt mark on his body.

            On scene, I observed the Honda. The key which was in Ocampo Cardona’s possession unlocked the driver’s door and trunk. The ignition cylinder was unable to be fully turned presumably due to airbag deployment and the steering wheel being locked in place. Inside the vehicle I observed multiple bottle caps. The seatbelt was pulled fully from the b-pilar and locked into place. This indicated that it was being worn at the time of the collision. Inside the center console, I located an insurance document for the vehicle with Ocampo Cardona’s name on it. The vehicle was photographed after it had been moved from the roadway by MDOT CHART.

            I walked the scene and observed the concrete barrier was impacted due to the debris field. The front-end damage observed on the Honda was consistent with a front-end impact with the barrier wall.

    Ocampo Cardona was advised his Miranda Rights on scene by TFC Lora and Ocampo Cardona waived his rights.
 
            Ocampo Cardona was escorted to the Maryland State Police Golden Ring Barrack for Standardized Field Sobriety Tests and processing. Once at the barrack, Ocampo Cardona was asked by TFC Lora if he consented to SFSTs and he agreed.


Pre-arrest Screening:
          
  All tests were conducted in front hallway within the barrack. All tests were explained and demonstrated with the translation from TFC Lora.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS TEST

His eyes were checked, and they displayed equal tracking and his pupils were equal sizes. Ocampo Cordona was instructed to follow the stimulus with his eyes only, keeping his head still. After stating that he understood the instructions, Ocampo Cordona attempted this test. No resting nystagmus was observed.
The results of this test displayed 6 of the 6 possible clues.
- A lack of smooth pursuit in the left eye
- A lack of smooth pursuit in the right eye
- A distinct and sustained nystagmus in the left eye at maximum deviation
- A distinct and sustained nystagmus in the right eye at maximum deviation
- An onset of nystagmus in the left eye prior to 45 degrees.
- An onset of nystagmus in the right eye prior to 45 degrees.


WALK AND TURN TEST

Ocampo Cordona was instructed to put his left foot on the line and his right foot in front of it with his right heel touching the toe of his left foot. He was instructed to stand in this manner with his hands to his sides until the test instructions were completed and the test demonstrated. Ocampo Cordona was instructed not to begin the test until told to start. He was instructed to take nine steps along the line in a heel-to-toe manner. After the ninth step he was to stop and turn around keeping his lead foot on the ground, taking several small steps with the other foot to turn around. After turning around, he was to take nine steps in a heel-to-toe manner back along the line, in the direction he had come from. Ocampo Cordona was further instructed to watch his feet at all times while walking, keep his arms down to his side, and to count his steps out loud. The test was demonstrated Ocampo Cordona. He asked to demonstrate the turn again and a second demonstration was completed. He stated that he understood the instructions and was instructed to begin the test.

The results of this test displayed 5 of the 8 possible clues:
He was unable to maintain his balance in the instructed position.
He started the test too soon.
During the test, he stopped while walking prior to the turn.
He turned improperly.
He used his arms once for balance.


ONE LEG STAND TEST
Ocampo Cordona was instructed to stand with his feet together and arms at his sides during the test. Ocampo Cordona was asked not to begin the test until instructed. He was instructed to raise the leg of his choice by approximately 6 inches off the ground. While holding that position, he was to keep his leg straight and count out loud starting at one thousand one (one thousand one, one thousand two, one thousand three, …) and so forth until instructed to stop (after 30 seconds). The test was demonstrated to Ocampo Cordona.

After he indicated understanding the instructions, Ocampo Cordona attempted the test and raised his left leg.
Ocampo Cordona’s foot was only raised slightly off of the ground. The test displayed 0 of the 4 possible clues.


Arrest:
Base on the following I had probable cause to arrest Ocampo Cordona for DUI:
  • Observing a blue Honda Civic with extensive front end damage abandoned in the middle of I-695.
  • Observed Ocampo Cordona actively fleeing from the vehicle
  • Ocampo Cordona failed to obey the order to stop when running.
  • Ocampo Cordona having an odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person.
  • Ocampo Cordona admitting to consuming alcohol prior to driving.
  • Indicators of impairment displayed during SFSTs
Ocampo Cordona was advised of his arrest at approximately 1626hrs. Ocampo Cordona was read the DR-15 Advice of Rights via Spanish audio and provided with the DR-15. The audio was obtained from the MVA Information for Law Enforcement website (https://mva.maryland.gov/Pages/police.aspx).  He was directed that the written Spanish was on the back and he began reading it at points as the audio was being played. After the audio was played and Ocampo Cordona read the form, he agreed to submit to an alcohol concentration test at 1640hrs and signed the DR-15.

Sgt Twardowski, a certified intoximeter operator, gave proper instruction which was translated to Ocampo Cordona by TFC Lora. Ocampo Cordona was able to successfully complete the test. His official results were .19 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath at 1703hrs.

Routine checks via METERS/NCIC were conducted on Ocampo Cordona. It revealed he had no record of a license in Maryland or any other state. Ocampo Cordona also admitted post-Miranda to not having a license. Ocampo Cordona also clarified when asked that he was drinking alcohol at his friends house in Dundalk. Ocampo Cordona admitted to consuming Corona. Ocampo Cordona was aksed about the PA temporary registration. He advised he let his friend borrow the car and that temporary registration was placed on the vehicle to avoid paying toll. Ocampo Cordona advised the registration came with the vehicle when he purchased it. Ocampo Cordona  was issued appropriate documentation and signed where requested per the documents.

After processing, Ocampo Cordona requested to go to the hospital complaining of chest pain. Baltimore County Fire Department Medic 12 responded. Ocampo Cordona was issued appropriate citations and given copies of all documents, and he was released from the barrack and transported to Franklin Square Hospital via Medic 12 (Run#230011474).


I request this case to be closed by arrest.

All events occurred in Baltimore County, Maryland.

MSP body-worn camera was operational. 

On January 1st, 2023, I, Trooper First Class Lora (#7207), responded to an accident scene on I695E, Philadelphia Rd, Baltimore County, Maryland, to assist Trooper First Class Wilson (#6512) with translation services. Soon after my arrival, I contacted TFC. Wilson and stood by until he requested my assistance. I identified the Hispanic Male as Ocampo Cardona , Hector Emilio, date of birth September 4th, 1993 via the information Mr. Ocampo verbally provided. Moments later, EMS arrived on the scene and I assisted with translation services to medical personnel. Mr. Ocampo Cardona expressed chest pain but refused to seek further medical attention on three occasions. Medical staff on the scene determined Mr. Ocampo's chest pain was related to the effects of proper seat belt usage. After that, I met TFC. Wilson at the Golden Ring Barracks to assist with translating SFST and intoximeter instructions. All events occurred in Baltimore County, Maryland.
